entry.title: Combined summary - Blinded 2-party Musig2
entry.summary: In a recent discussion on the bitcoin-dev mailing list, the implementation of a blinded version of the 2-of-2 Schnorr MuSig2 for statechains is being discussed. The goal of this implementation is to have a server (party 1) that holds a private key required for generating an aggregate signature but does not learn certain information such as the aggregate public key, aggregate signature, or the message being signed. The security relies on trusting the statechain server to report the number of partial signatures generated and verifying the full set of signatures on the client side.The MuSig2 protocol involves both party 1 and party 2 generating private keys and corresponding public keys. The shared public key is obtained by multiplying the individual public keys with their respective coefficients calculated using a cryptographic hash function. To sign a message, both parties generate nonce values, compute a challenge value, and then compute their individual signatures. The final signature is obtained by combining the aggregated nonce with the sum of the individual signatures.In the case of blinding for party 1, adjustments are made. Party 1 only sends its public key and aggregated nonce to party 2, who performs key and nonce aggregation. Party 2 computes the challenge value and sends it to party 1, who can then compute their individual signature without learning the final value of the signature or the message.There are discussions about the vulnerability of this scheme to specific attacks, such as manipulating R-values. Potential issues and alternative schemes are raised and debated. It is suggested that further research and analysis are needed to address these concerns and ensure the security of the proposed blinded statechains implementation.Additionally, there is mention of a concern about party 1 not learning the final value of (R, s1+s2) or the message. A suggestion is made to include a step where the server can scan the blockchain for signatures and compute corresponding hashes to verify the authenticity of the received values without directly accessing the final values.The discussion also explores other topics related to blind Schnorr signatures and potential vulnerabilities. The effectiveness of blinding the challenge in the signing protocol is discussed, as well as the need for additional measures to ensure the integrity of cryptographic protocols. Different approaches and considerations are explored to enhance the security and privacy features of the bitcoin protocol.Overall, the discussion showcases ongoing efforts to refine the implementation of a blinded version of the 2-of-2 Schnorr MuSig2 for statechains, address potential vulnerabilities, and ensure the security and privacy of transactions.
